items.name: Ext.draw.sprite.Image
items.text: A sprite that represents an image.

items.name: dirty
items.text:
Current state of the sprite.
Set to `true` if the sprite needs to be repainted.

items.name: fillOpacity
items.text: The opacity of the fill. Limited from 0 to 1.

items.name: fillStyle
items.text: The color of the shape (a CSS color value).

items.name: globalAlpha
items.text: The opacity of the sprite. Limited from 0 to 1.

items.name: globalCompositeOperation
items.text:
Indicates how source images are drawn onto a destination image.
globalCompositeOperation attribute is not supported by the SVG and VML (excanvas) engines.

items.name: height
items.text:
The height of the image.
For consistent image size on all devices the height must be explicitly set.
Otherwise the natural image height devided by the device pixel ratio
(for a crisp looking image) will be used as the height of the sprite.

items.name: hidden
items.text: Determines whether or not the sprite is hidden.

items.name: lineCap
items.text: The style of the line caps.

items.name: lineDash
items.text:
[lineDash=[]]
An even number of non-negative numbers specifying a dash/space sequence.
Note that while this is supported in IE8 (VML engine), the behavior is
different from Canvas and SVG. Please refer to this document for details:
http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/bb264085(v=vs.85).aspx
Although IE9 and IE10 have Canvas support, the 'lineDash'
attribute is not supported in those browsers.

items.name: lineDashOffset
items.text: A number specifying how far into the line dash sequence drawing commences.

items.name: lineJoin
items.text: The style of the line join.

items.name: lineWidth
items.text: The width of the line stroke.

items.name: listeners
miterLimit
items.text: Sets the distance between the inner corner and the outer corner where two lines meet.

items.name: parent
items.text: The immediate parent of the sprite. Not necessarily a surface.

items.name: path
items.text: The SVG based path string used by the sprite.

items.name: radius
items.text: The radius of the rounded corners.

items.name: rotation
rads
items.text: The angle in radians to rotate the sprite

items.name: degrees
items.text: The angle in degrees to rotate the sprite (is ignored if rads or rotationRads is set

items.name: centerX
items.text:
The central coordinate of the sprite's rotation on the x-axis.
Unless explicitly set, will default to the calculated center of the
sprite along the x-axis.

items.name: centerY
items.text:
The central coordinate of the sprite's rotation on the y-axis.
Unless explicitly set, will default to the calculated center of the
sprite along the y-axis.

items.name: rotationCenterX
items.text: The central coordinate of the sprite's scale operation on the x-axis. Unless explicitly set, will default to the calculated center of the sprite along the x-axis. **Note:** Transform configs are *always* performed in the following order: 1. Scaling 2. Rotation 3. Translation See also: rotation, rotationRads, and rotationCenterY

items.name: rotationCenterY
items.text: The central coordinate of the sprite's rotate operation on the y-axis. Unless explicitly set, will default to the calculated center of the sprite along the y-axis. **Note:** Transform configs are *always* performed in the following order: 1. Scaling 2. Rotation 3. Translation See also: rotation, rotationRads, and rotationCenterX

items.name: rotationRads
items.text: The angle of rotation of the sprite in radians. **Note:** Transform configs are *always* performed in the following order: 1. Scaling 2. Rotation 3. Translation See also: rotation, rotationCenterX, and rotationCenterY

items.name: scaling
items.text: Applies initial scaling to the sprite. May be a number specifying the amount to scale both the x and y-axis. The number value represents a percentage by which to scale the sprite. **1** is equal to 100%, **2** would be 200%, etc. Or may be a config object using the below config options. **Note:** Scaling config options will be overridden by values set on the scalingX, scalingY, scalingCenterX, and scalingCenterY configs. Ext.create({ xtype: 'draw', renderTo: Ext.getBody(), width: 600, height: 400, sprites: [{ type: 'rect', x: 50, y: 50, width: 100, height: 100, fillStyle: '#1F6D91', //scaling: 2, scaling: { x: 2, y: 2 //centerX: 100, //centerY: 100 } }] }); **Note:** Transform configs are *always* performed in the following order: 1. Scaling 2. Rotation 3. Translation

items.name: x
items.text:
The amount by which to scale the sprite along the x-axis.  The number
value represents a percentage by which to scale the sprite.  **1** is
equal to 100%, **2** would be 200%, etc.

items.name: y
items.text:
The amount by which to scale the sprite along the y-axis.  The number
value represents a percentage by which to scale the sprite.  **1** is
equal to 100%, **2** would be 200%, etc.

items.name: centerX
items.text:
The central coordinate of the sprite's scaling on the x-axis.  Unless
explicitly set, will default to the calculated center of the sprite
along the x-axis.

items.name: centerY
items.text:
The central coordinate of the sprite's scaling on the y-axis.  Unless
explicitly set, will default to the calculated center of the sprite
along the y-axis.

items.name: scalingCenterX
items.text: The central coordinate of the sprite's scale operation on the x-axis. **Note:** Transform configs are *always* performed in the following order: 1. Scaling 2. Rotation 3. Translation See also: scaling, scalingX, scalingY, and scalingCenterY

items.name: scalingCenterY
items.text: The central coordinate of the sprite's scale operation on the y-axis. **Note:** Transform configs are *always* performed in the following order: 1. Scaling 2. Rotation 3. Translation See also: scaling, scalingX, scalingY, and scalingCenterX

items.name: scalingX
items.text: The scaling of the sprite on the x-axis. The number value represents a percentage by which to scale the sprite. **1** is equal to 100%, **2** would be 200%, etc. **Note:** Transform configs are *always* performed in the following order: 1. Scaling 2. Rotation 3. Translation See also: scaling, scalingY, scalingCenterX, and scalingCenterY

items.name: scalingY
items.text: The scaling of the sprite on the y-axis. The number value represents a percentage by which to scale the sprite. **1** is equal to 100%, **2** would be 200%, etc. **Note:** Transform configs are *always* performed in the following order: 1. Scaling 2. Rotation 3. Translation See also: scaling, scalingX, scalingCenterX, and scalingCenterY

items.name: shadowBlur
items.text: The amount blur used on the shadow.

items.name: shadowColor
items.text: The color of the shadow (a CSS color value).

items.name: shadowOffsetX
items.text: The offset of the sprite's shadow on the x-axis.

items.name: shadowOffsetY
items.text: The offset of the sprite's shadow on the y-axis.

items.name: src
items.text: The image source of the sprite.

items.name: strokeOpacity
items.text: The opacity of the stroke. Limited from 0 to 1.

items.name: strokeStyle
items.text: The color of the stroke (a CSS color value).

items.name: surface
items.text: The surface that this sprite is rendered into.

items.name: transformFillStroke
items.text: Determines whether the fill and stroke are affected by sprite transformations.

items.name: translation
items.text: Applies an initial translation, adjustment in x/y positioning, to the sprite. **Note:** Translation config options will be overridden by values set on the translationX and translationY configs. Ext.create({ xtype: 'draw', renderTo: Ext.getBody(), width: 600, height: 400, sprites: [{ type: 'rect', x: 50, y: 50, width: 100, height: 100, fillStyle: '#1F6D91', translation: { x: 50, y: 50 } }] }); **Note:** Transform configs are *always* performed in the following order: 1. Scaling 2. Rotation 3. Translation

items.name: x
items.text: The amount to translate the sprite along the x-axis.

items.name: y
items.text: The amount to translate the sprite along the y-axis.

items.name: translationX
items.text: The translation, position offset, of the sprite on the x-axis. **Note:** Transform configs are *always* performed in the following order: 1. Scaling 2. Rotation 3. Translation See also: translation and translationY

items.name: translationY
items.text: The translation, position offset, of the sprite on the y-axis. **Note:** Transform configs are *always* performed in the following order: 1. Scaling 2. Rotation 3. Translation See also: translation and translationX

items.name: width
items.text:
The width of the image.
For consistent image size on all devices the width must be explicitly set.
Otherwise the natural image width devided by the device pixel ratio
(for a crisp looking image) will be used as the width of the sprite.

items.name: x
items.text: The position of the sprite on the x-axis.

items.name: y
items.text: The position of the sprite on the y-axis.

items.name: zIndex
items.text: The stacking order of the sprite.

items.name: _addDeclaredListeners
items.text: Adds declarative listeners as nested arrays of listener objects.
`true` if any listeners were added

items.name: addAfterListener
items.text: Alias for onAfter.

items.name: addBeforeListener
items.text: Alias for onBefore.

items.name: addListener
eventName
items.text:
The name of the event to listen for.
May also be an object who's property names are event names.

items.name: fn
items.text: The method the event invokes or the *name* of the method within the specified `scope`. Will be called with arguments given to Ext.util.Observable#fireEvent plus the `options` parameter described below.

items.name: scope
items.text:
The scope (`this` reference) in which the handler function is
executed. **If omitted, defaults to the object which fired the event.**

items.name: options
items.text:
An object containing handler configuration.

**Note:** The options object will also be passed as the last argument to every
event handler.

This object may contain any of the following properties:

items.name: scope
items.text:
The scope (`this` reference) in which the handler function is executed. **If omitted,
  defaults to the object which fired the event.**

items.name: delay
items.text:
The number of milliseconds to delay the invocation of the handler after the event
  fires.

items.name: single
items.text:
True to add a handler to handle just the next firing of the event, and then remove
  itself.

items.name: buffer
items.text: Causes the handler to be scheduled to run in an Ext.util.DelayedTask delayed by the specified number of milliseconds. If the event fires again within that time, the original handler is _not_ invoked, but the new handler is scheduled in its place.

items.name: onFrame
items.text: Causes the handler to be scheduled to run at the next Ext.Function#requestAnimationFrame. If the event fires again before that time, the handler is not rescheduled - the handler will only be called once when the next animation frame is fired, with the last set of arguments passed.

items.name: target
items.text:
Only call the handler if the event was fired on the target Observable, _not_ if the
  event was bubbled up from a child Observable.

items.name: element
items.text: **This option is only valid for listeners bound to Ext.Component.** The name of a Component property which references an Ext.dom.Element to add a listener to. This option is useful during Component construction to add DOM event listeners to elements of Ext.Component which will exist only after the Component is rendered. For example, to add a click listener to a Panel's body: var panel = new Ext.panel.Panel({ title: 'The title', listeners: { click: this.handlePanelClick, element: 'body' } }); In order to remove listeners attached using the element, you'll need to reference the element itself as seen below. panel.body.un(...)

items.name: delegate
items.text:
A simple selector to filter the event target or look for a descendant of the target.

  The "delegate" option is only available on Ext.dom.Element instances (or
  when attaching a listener to a Ext.dom.Element via a Component using the
  element option).

  See the *delegate* example below.

items.name: stopPropagation
items.text: **This option is only valid for listeners bound to Ext.dom.Element.** `true` to call Ext.event.Event#stopPropagation on the event object before firing the handler.

items.name: preventDefault
items.text: **This option is only valid for listeners bound to Ext.dom.Element.** `true` to call Ext.event.Event#preventDefault on the event object before firing the handler.

items.name: stopEvent
items.text: **This option is only valid for listeners bound to Ext.dom.Element.** `true` to call Ext.event.Event#stopEvent on the event object before firing the handler.

items.name: args
items.text: Optional arguments to pass to the handler function. Any additional arguments passed to Ext.util.Observable#fireEvent will be appended to these arguments.

items.name: destroyable
items.text: When specified as `true`, the function returns a `destroyable` object. An object which implements the destroy method which removes all listeners added in this call. This syntax can be a helpful shortcut to using un; particularly when removing multiple listeners. *NOTE* - not compatible when using the _element_ option. See un for the proper syntax for removing listeners added using the _element_ config.

items.name: priority
items.text:
An optional numeric priority that determines the order in which event handlers
  are run. Event handlers with no priority will be run as if they had a priority
  of 0. Handlers with a higher priority will be prioritized to run sooner than
  those with a lower priority.  Negative numbers can be used to set a priority
  lower than the default. Internally, the framework uses a range of 1000 or
  greater, and -1000 or lesser for handlers that are intended to run before or
  after all others, so it is recommended to stay within the range of -999 to 999
  when setting the priority of event handlers in application-level code.
  A priority must be an integer to be valid.  Fractional values are reserved for
  internal framework use.

items.name: order
items.text:
A legacy option that is provided for backward compatibility.
  It is recommended to use the `priority` option instead.  Available options are:

  - `'before'`: equal to a priority of `100`
  - `'current'`: equal to a priority of `0` or default priority
  - `'after'`: equal to a priority of `-100`

items.name: order
addManagedListener
item
items.text: The item to which to add a listener/listeners.

items.name: ename
items.text: The event name, or an object containing event name properties.

items.name: fn
items.text:
(optional) If the `ename` parameter was an event
name, this is the handler function or the name of a method on the specified
`scope`.

items.name: scope
items.text:
(optional) If the `ename` parameter was an event name, this is the scope (`this` reference)
in which the handler function is executed.

items.name: options
items.text: (optional) If the `ename` parameter was an event name, this is the Ext.util.Observable#addListener options.

items.name: applyTransformations
items.text:
Calculates forward and inverse transform matrices from sprite's attributes.
Transformations are applied in the following order: Scaling, Rotation, Translation.

items.name: force
items.text:
Forces recalculation of transform matrices even when
sprite's transform attributes supposedly haven't changed.

items.name: callUpdaters
items.text: Calls updaters triggered by changes to sprite attributes.

items.name: attr
items.text: The attributes of a sprite or its instance.

items.name: clearListeners
items.text: Removes all listeners for this object including the managed listeners

items.name: clearManagedListeners
items.text: Removes all managed listeners for this object.

items.name: createRelayer
items.text: Creates an event handling function which re-fires the event from this object as the passed event name.

items.name: newName
items.text: The name under which to re-fire the passed parameters.

items.name: beginEnd
items.text: (optional) The caller can specify on which indices to slice.

items.name: destroy
items.text: Removes the sprite and clears all listeners.

items.name: doFireEvent
items.text: Continue to fire event.

items.name: enableBubble
eventNames
items.text: The event name to bubble, or an Array of event names.

items.name: fireAction
items.text: Fires the specified event with the passed parameters and executes a function (action). By default, the action function will be executed after any "before" event handlers (as specified using the `order` option of Ext.util.Observable#addListener), but before any other handlers are fired. This gives the "before" handlers an opportunity to cancel the event by returning `false`, and prevent the action function from being called. The action can also be configured to run after normal handlers, but before any "after" handlers (as specified using the `order` event option) by passing `'after'` as the `order` parameter. This configuration gives any event handlers except for "after" handlers the opportunity to cancel the event and prevent the action function from being called.

items.name: eventName
items.text: The name of the event to fire.

items.name: args
items.text: Arguments to pass to handlers and to the action function.

items.name: fn
items.text: The action function.

items.name: scope
items.text:
The scope (`this` reference) in which the handler function is
executed. **If omitted, defaults to the object which fired the event.**

items.name: options
items.text: Event options for the action function. Accepts any of the options of Ext.util.Observable#addListener

items.name: order
items.text: The order to call the action function relative too the event handlers (`'before'` or `'after'`). Note that this option is simply used to sort the action function relative to the event handlers by "priority". An order of `'before'` is equivalent to a priority of `99.5`, while an order of `'after'` is equivalent to a priority of `-99.5`. See the `priority` option of Ext.util.Observable#addListener for more details.

items.name: fireEvent
items.text: Fires the specified event with the passed parameters (minus the event name, plus the `options` object passed to Ext.util.Observable#addListener). An event may be set to bubble up an Observable parent hierarchy (See Ext.Component#getBubbleTarget) by calling enableBubble.

items.name: eventName
items.text: The name of the event to fire.

items.name: args
items.text: Variable number of parameters are passed to handlers.
returns false if any of the handlers return false otherwise it returns true.

items.name: fireEventArgs
items.text: Fires the specified event with the passed parameter list. An event may be set to bubble up an Observable parent hierarchy (See Ext.Component#getBubbleTarget) by calling enableBubble.

items.name: eventName
items.text: The name of the event to fire.

items.name: args
items.text: An array of parameters which are passed to handlers.
returns false if any of the handlers return false otherwise it returns true.

items.name: fireEventedAction
items.text:
Fires the specified event with the passed parameters and executes a function (action).
Evented Actions will automatically dispatch a 'before' event passing. This event will
be given a special controller that allows for pausing/resuming of the event flow.

By pausing the controller the updater and events will not run until resumed. Pausing,
however, will not stop the processing of any other before events.

items.name: eventName
items.text: The name of the event to fire.

items.name: args
items.text: Arguments to pass to handlers and to the action function.

items.name: fn
items.text: The action function.

items.name: scope
items.text:
The scope (`this` reference) in which the handler function is
executed. **If omitted, defaults to the object which fired the event.**

items.name: fnArgs
items.text:
Optional arguments for the action `fn`. If not
given, the normal `args` will be used to call `fn`. If `false` is passed, the
`args` are used but if the first argument is this instance it will be removed
from the args passed to the action function.

items.name: getAnimation
items.text:
Returns the current animation instance.
return {Ext.draw.modifier.Animation} The animation modifier used to animate the
sprite

items.name: getBBox
items.text: Returns the bounding box for the given Sprite as calculated with the Canvas engine.

items.name: isWithoutTransform
items.text: Whether to calculate the bounding box with the current transforms or not.

items.name: getBBoxCenter
items.text: Subclass can rewrite this function to gain better performance.

items.name: getBubbleParent
items.text: Gets the bubbling parent for an Observable
The bubble parent. null is returned if no bubble target exists

items.name: getId
items.text: Retrieves the id of this component. Will autogenerate an id if one has not already been set.
id

items.name: hasListener
items.text:
Checks to see if this object has any listeners for a specified event, or whether the event bubbles. The answer
indicates whether the event needs firing or not.

items.name: eventName
items.text: The name of the event to check for
`true` if the event is being listened for or bubbles, else `false`

items.name: hide
items.text: Hide the sprite.
this

items.name: hitTest
items.text: Performs a hit test on the sprite.

items.name: point
items.text: A two-item array containing x and y coordinates of the point.

items.name: options
items.text: Hit testing options.

A hit result object that contains more information about what
exactly was hit or null if nothing was hit.

items.name: isSuspended
items.text: Checks if all events, or a specific event, is suspended.

items.name: event
items.text: The name of the specific event to check
`true` if events are suspended

items.name: isVisible
items.text: Checks if the sprite can be seen. This includes the hidden attribute check, alpha/opacity checks, fill/stroke color checks and surface/parent checks. The method doesn't check if the sprite is off-screen.
Returns `true`, if the sprite can be seen.

items.name: mon
items.text: Shorthand for addManagedListener.

items.name: mun
items.text: Shorthand for removeManagedListener.

items.name: onAfter
items.text: Appends an after-event handler. Same as Ext.util.Observable#addListener with `order` set to `'after'`.

items.name: eventName
items.text: The name of the event to listen for.

items.name: fn
items.text: The method the event invokes.

items.name: scope
items.text: The scope for `fn`.

items.name: options
items.text: An object containing handler configuration.

items.name: onBefore
items.text: Appends a before-event handler. Returning `false` from the handler will stop the event. Same as Ext.util.Observable#addListener with `order` set to `'before'`.

items.name: eventName
items.text: The name of the event to listen for.

items.name: fn
items.text: The method the event invokes.

items.name: scope
items.text: The scope for `fn`.

items.name: options
items.text: An object containing handler configuration.

items.name: relayEvents
items.text:
Relays selected events from the specified Observable as if the events were fired by `this`.

For example if you are extending Grid, you might decide to forward some events from store.
So you can do this inside your initComponent:

    this.relayEvents(this.getStore(), ['load']);

The grid instance will then have an observable 'load' event which will be passed
the parameters of the store's load event and any function fired with the grid's
load event would have access to the grid using the this keyword (unless the event
is handled by a controller's control/listen event listener in which case 'this'
will be the controller rather than the grid).

items.name: origin
items.text: The Observable whose events this object is to relay.

items.name: events
items.text:
Array of event names to relay or an Object with key/value
pairs translating to ActualEventName/NewEventName respectively. For example:
    this.relayEvents(this, {add:'push', remove:'pop'});

Would now redispatch the add event of this as a push event and the remove event as a pop event.

items.name: prefix
remove
items.text:
Removes this sprite from its surface.
The sprite itself is not destroyed.
Returns the removed sprite or null otherwise.

items.name: removeAfterListener
items.text: Alias for unAfter.

items.name: removeBeforeListener
items.text: Alias for unBefore.

items.name: removeListener
items.text: Removes an event handler.

items.name: eventName
items.text: The type of event the handler was associated with.

items.name: fn
items.text: The handler to remove. **This must be a reference to the function passed into the Ext.util.Observable#addListener call.**

items.name: scope
removeManagedListener
items.text: Removes listeners that were added by the mon method.

items.name: item
items.text: The item from which to remove a listener/listeners.

items.name: ename
items.text: The event name, or an object containing event name properties.

items.name: fn
items.text: (optional) If the `ename` parameter was an event name, this is the handler function.

items.name: scope
items.text:
(optional) If the `ename` parameter was an event name, this is the scope (`this` reference)
in which the handler function is executed.

items.name: removeManagedListenerItem
items.text: Remove a single managed listener item

items.name: isClear
items.text: True if this is being called during a clear

items.name: managedListener
items.text:
The managed listener item
See removeManagedListener for other args

items.name: render
items.text: Render method.

items.name: surface
items.text: The surface.

items.name: ctx
items.text: A context object compatible with CanvasRenderingContext2D.

items.name: rect
items.text:
The clip rect (or called dirty rect) of the current rendering. Not to be confused
with `surface.getRect()`.

returns `false` to stop rendering in this frame.
All the sprites that haven't been rendered will have their dirty flag untouched.

items.name: renderBBox
items.text: Renders the bounding box of transformed sprite.

items.name: resetTransform
items.text: Resets current transformation matrix of a sprite to the identify matrix.

items.name: isSplit
items.text: If 'true', transformation attributes are updated.
This sprite.

items.name: resolveListenerScope
items.text:
Gets the default scope for firing late bound events (string names with
no scope attached) at runtime.

items.name: defaultScope
items.text: The default scope to return if none is found.
The default event scope

items.name: resumeEvent
items.text: Resumes firing of the named event(s). After calling this method to resume events, the events will fire when requested to fire. **Note that if the suspendEvent method is called multiple times for a certain event, this converse method will have to be called the same number of times for it to resume firing.**

items.name: eventName
items.text: Multiple event names to resume.

items.name: resumeEvents
items.text: Resumes firing events (see suspendEvents). If events were suspended using the `queueSuspended` parameter, then all events fired during event suspension will be sent to any listeners now.

items.name: discardQueue
items.text: `true` to prevent any previously queued events from firing while we were suspended. See suspendEvents.

items.name: attr
items.text: The attributes object (not necesseraly of a sprite, but of its instance).

items.name: updater
items.text: Updater to be called.

items.name: triggers
items.text: Attributes that triggered the update.

items.name: scheduleUpdaters
attr
items.text: The attributes object (not necesseraly of a sprite, but of its instance).

items.name: updaters
items.text: A map of updaters to be called to attributes that triggered the update.

items.name: triggers
items.text:
Attributes that triggered the update. An optional parameter.
If used, the `updaters` parameter will be treated as an array of updaters to be called.

items.name: setAnimation
config
items.text:
The Ext.draw.modifier.Animation config for this sprite's
animations.

items.name: setAttributes
items.text: Set attributes of the sprite. By default only the attributes that have processors will be set and all other attributes will be filtered out as a result of the normalization process. The normalization process can be skipped. In that case all the given attributes will be set unprocessed. This will result in better performance, but might also pollute the sprite's attributes with unwanted attributes or attributes with invalid values, if one is not careful. See also setAttributesBypassingNormalization. If normalization is skipped, one may also chose to avoid copying the given object. This may result in even better performance, but only in cases where most of the attributes have values that are different from the old values, because copying additionally checks if the value has changed.

items.name: changes
items.text: The content of the change.

items.name: bypassNormalization
items.text: `true` to avoid normalization of the given changes.

items.name: avoidCopy
items.text:
`true` to avoid copying the `changes` object.
`bypassNormalization` should also be `true`. The content of object may be destroyed.

items.deprecatedMessage: setAttributes directy with bypassNormalization argument being `true`.
items.name: setAttributesBypassingNormalization
items.text:
Set attributes of the sprite, assuming the names and values have already been
normalized.

items.name: changes
items.text: The content of the change.

items.name: avoidCopy
items.text:
`true` to avoid copying the `changes` object.
The content of object may be destroyed.

items.name: setListeners
items.text: An alias for Ext.util.Observable#addListener. In versions prior to 5.1, listeners had a generated setter which could be called to add listeners. In 5.1 the listeners config is not processed using the config system and has no generated setter, so this method is provided for backward compatibility. The preferred way of adding listeners is to use the on method.

items.name: listeners
items.text: The listeners

items.name: setTransform
items.text:
Resets current transformation matrix of a sprite to the identify matrix and pre-multiplies it with the given matrix. This is effectively the same as calling resetTransform, followed by transform with the same arguments. See also: transform var drawContainer = new Ext.draw.Container({ renderTo: Ext.getBody(), width: 380, height: 380, sprites: [{ type: 'rect', width: 100, height: 100, fillStyle: 'red' }] }); var main = drawContainer.getSurface(); var rect = main.getItems()[0]; var m = new Ext.draw.Matrix().rotate(Math.PI, 100, 100); rect.setTransform(m); main.renderFrame(); There may be times where the transformation you need to apply cannot easily be accomplished using the sprite’s convenience transform methods. Or, you may want to pass a matrix directly to the sprite in order to set a transformation. The setTransform method allows for this sort of advanced usage as well. The following tables show each transformation matrix used when applying transformations to a sprite. ### Translate
1 0 tx
0 1 ty
0 0 1
### Rotate (θ is the angle of rotation)
cos(θ) -sin(θ) 0
0 cos(θ) 0
0 0 1
### Scale
sx 0 0
0 cos(θ) 0
0 0 1
### Shear X _(λ is the distance on the x axis to shear by)_
1 λx 0
0 1 0
0 0 1
### Shear Y (λ is the distance on the y axis to shear by)
1 0 0
λy 1 0
0 0 1
### Skew X (θ is the angle to skew by)
1 tan(θ) 0
0 1 0
0 0 1
### Skew Y (θ is the angle to skew by)
1 0 0
tan(θ) 1 0
0 0 1
Multiplying matrices for translation, rotation, scaling, and shearing / skewing any number of times in the desired order produces a single matrix for a composite transformation. You can use the product as a value for the setTransformmethod of a sprite: mySprite.setTransform([a, b, c, d, e, f]); Where `a`, `b`, `c`, `d`, `e`, `f` are numeric values that correspond to the following transformation matrix components:
a c e
b d f
0 0 1

items.name: matrix
items.text:
The transformation matrix to apply or its
raw elements as an array.

items.name: isSplit
items.text: If `true`, transformation attributes are updated.
This sprite.

items.name: show
items.text: Show the sprite.
this

items.name: suspendEvent
items.text: Suspends firing of the named event(s). After calling this method to suspend events, the events will no longer fire when requested to fire. **Note that if this is called multiple times for a certain event, the converse method resumeEvent will have to be called the same number of times for it to resume firing.**

items.name: eventName
items.text: Multiple event names to suspend.

items.name: suspendEvents
items.text: Suspends the firing of all events. (see resumeEvents)

items.name: queueSuspended
items.text: `true` to queue up suspended events to be fired after the resumeEvents call instead of discarding all suspended events.

items.name: transform
items.text: Pre-multiplies the current transformation matrix of a sprite with the given matrix. If `isSplit` parameter is `true`, the resulting matrix is also split into individual components (scaling, rotation, translation) and corresponding sprite attributes are updated. The shearing component is not extracted. Note, that transformation attributes work as if transformations are applied to the local coordinate system of a sprite, while matrix transformations transform the global coordinate space or the surface grid. Since the transform method returns the sprite itself, calls to the method can be chained. And if updating sprite transformation attributes is desired, it can be achieved by setting the `isSplit` parameter of the last call to `true`. For example: sprite.transform(matrixA).transform(matrixB).transform(matrixC, true); See also: setTransform

items.name: matrix
items.text: A transformation matrix or array of its elements.

items.name: isSplit
items.text: If 'true', transformation attributes are updated.
This sprite.

items.name: un
items.text: Shorthand for removeListener.

items.name: unAfter
items.text: Removes a before-event handler. Same as removeListener with `order` set to `'after'`.

items.name: eventName
items.text: The name of the event the handler was associated with.

items.name: fn
items.text: The handler to remove.

items.name: scope
items.text: The scope originally specified for `fn`.

items.name: options
items.text: Extra options object.

items.name: unBefore
items.text: Removes a before-event handler. Same as removeListener with `order` set to `'before'`.

items.name: eventName
items.text: The name of the event the handler was associated with.

items.name: fn
items.text: The handler to remove.

items.name: scope
items.text: The scope originally specified for `fn`.

items.name: options
items.text: Extra options object.

items.name: updatePath
items.text: Update the path.

items.name: path
items.text: An empty path to draw on using path API.

items.name: attr
items.text:
The attribute object. Note: DO NOT use the `sprite.attr` instead of this
if you want to work with instancing.

items.name: updatePlainBBox
items.text: Subclass will fill the plain object with x, y, width, height information of the plain bounding box of this sprite.

items.name: plain
items.text: Target object.

items.name: updateTransformedBBox
items.text: Subclass will fill the plain object with x, y, width, height information of the transformed bounding box of this sprite.

items.name: transform
items.text: Target object (transformed bounding box) to populate.

items.name: plain
items.text: Untransformed bounding box.

items.name: useAttributes
items.text: Applies sprite's attributes to the given context.

items.name: ctx
items.text: Context to apply sprite's attributes to.

items.name: rect
items.text: The rect of the context to be affected by gradients.

items.name: $eventOptions
items.text: Matches options property names within a listeners specification object  - property names which are never used as event names.

items.name: attr
items.text: The visual attributes of the sprite, e.g. strokeStyle, fillStyle, lineWidth...

items.name: eventsSuspended
items.text: Initial suspended call count. Incremented when suspendEvents is called, decremented when resumeEvents is called.

items.name: hasListeners
items.text: This object holds a key for any event that has a listener. The listener may be set directly on the instance, or on its class or a super class (via observe) or on the Ext.app.EventBus. The values of this object are truthy (a non-zero number) and falsy (0 or undefined). They do not represent an exact count of listeners. The value for an event is truthy if the event must be fired and is falsy if there is no need to fire the event. The intended use of this property is to avoid the expense of fireEvent calls when there are no listeners. This can be particularly helpful when one would otherwise have to call fireEvent hundreds or thousands of times. It is used like this: if (this.hasListeners.foo) { this.fireEvent('foo', this, arg1); }

items.name: isObservable
items.text: `true` in this class to identify an object as an instantiated Observable, or subclass thereof.

items.name: preRender
items.text: Called before rendering.
